[Class FloatImage]

Functions

FLOAT32 kF_GetPixel (int x, int y, const TFloatImage *pInfo)
 returns the pixel value at position (x,y), including range check, slow access.

FLOAT32 kF_GetPixelFast (int x, int y, const TFloatImage *pInfo)
 returns the pixel value at position (x,y), without range check, fast access.

 Sets a pixel at position (x,y), including range check, slow access.

bool kF_SetPixelFast (int x, int y, FLOAT32 Color, TFloatImage *pInfo)
 sets a pixel at position (x,y), without range check, fast access.

FLOAT32 kF_GetPixelInterpolated (float x, float y, const TFloatImage *pInfo)
 returns the interpolated value at position (x,y), including range check.

FLOAT32 kF_GetPixelInterpolatedFast (float x, float y, const TFloatImage *pInfo)
 A faster version of kF_GetPixelInterpolated(), no range checking and origo must be (0,0).

Detailed Description

Kernel ANSI C only routines, last updated 12/5/1999.

Basic FloatImage functions to be used as stand alone c functions only. The C++ part does not use these functions.

Version:
1.00
Author:
René Dencker Eriksen edr@mip.sdu.dk

Define Documentation

#define kF_GetPixelMacro (  x,
y,
Image    )     ((Image).ppMatrix[y][x])
 

Macro function for accessing pixels in a float image.

The macro is very fast, but be carefull when using the macro, there are no type and range checking. Orego always (0,0).

Parameters:
x  (int) x-position
y  (int) y-position
Image  (TFloatImage) The image to access pixel in.

Definition at line 369 of file f_kernel_functions.h.

#define kF_SetPixelMacro (  x,
y,
Color,
Image    )     ((Image).ppMatrix[y][x]=Color);
 

Macro function for setting pixels in a float image.

The macro is very fast, but be carefull when using the macro, there are no type and range checking. Orego always (0,0).

Parameters:
x  (int) x-position
y  (int) y-position
Image  (TFloatImage) The image to set pixel in.

float    y,
const TFloatImage *    pInfo
) 
 

returns the interpolated value at position (x,y), including range check.

Uses bilinar interpolation.

y  The position in vertical direction
